body: ## Problem: When using 'diffopt=inline:word', lines were excessively fragmented with punctuation creating separate highlight blocks, making it harder to read the diffs. ## Solution: This PR replaces the old behavior of fragmentation in between words separated by 'spaces' or 'punctuation' to joining those words together and add a new `wordgap` option for `'diffopt'` to configure this behavior. Which when enabled `inline:word` is enabled the default value of `wordgap:2` is used to provide continuous block of diff. - This creates more readable diffs and closely matches GitHub's own diff display. ### `set diffopt=internal,filler,inline:word,wordgap:0` ### `set diffopt=internal,filler,inline:word,wordgap:2` (default) ### `set diffopt=internal,filler,inline:word,wordgap:5` (max) ## Backwards Compatibility - The new behavior is **default** with configurable `wordgap:` option: `wordgap:0` to `wordgap:5`, where `wordgap:2` is default - Old behavior of `inline:word` can still be able to be used, using `wordgap:0` ## Usage Enable with: ``` :set diffopt+=inline:word,wordgap:(0-5) ``` ## Implementation - Adds the **diff_refine_inline_word_highlight()** implementation in C to merge word fragments separated by punctuation or whitespace (‚â§2 bytes) with configurable option of `wordgap`. - Option parsing, docs, and completion support included. ## Tests - Added/updated functional tests to cover: - Updated tests for `inline:word` to support the new behavior by default - Edge cases: multi-byte, iwhite, iwhiteeol, punctuation, 3-buffer diffs - Added new tests for different cases of `wordgap`, e.g. `wordgap:0`, `wordgap:2`, `wordgap:5` ## Documentation - Updated `:help diff`, options, and news/changelog/documentation for the new option. This creates more readable and is similar to github diff behaviour with backward compactibility. Fixes #37019

So the functional tests failed in tests/functional/ui/diff_spec.lua which is expected as I have changed how the Diff works for `inline:word` in diff.c

But the outputs of the failed tests shows that, the result we got from the tests are working as intended.

Like:
`:set diffopt=internal,filler,inline:word`

```
Expected:
|*{7:  }{27:^abcdef}{4: }{27:ghi}{4: }{27:jk}{4: n }‚îÇ{7:  }{27:aBcef}{4: }{27:gHi}{4: }{27:lm}{4: n  }|
           |---------------------------------|
                     Separated by spaces
```

```
Actual:
|*{7:  }{27:^abcdef ghi jk}{4: n }‚îÇ{7:  }{27:aBcef gHi lm}{4: n  }|
          |-----------------|
        Highlighted Together
```

Another Test :- 

Expected:
```
|*{7:  }{27:^This+is}{4:=}{27:a}{4:-setence      }‚îÇ{7:  }{27:This+is}{4:=}{27:another}{4:-setenc}‚îÇ{7:  }{27:That+is}{4:=}{27:a}{4:-setence     }|

{27:^This+is}{4:=}{27:a} : Separated by '='
```

Actual:
```

         |---------------|
            Highlighted
            Together
```

This shows my changes are working as intended and the test should be updated.

Even though I was hesitant to update the test files, but I think this is the most logical way for to implement something like this.

Why is this optional? Who wants the old behavior?

I have lost track of how much we forked diff-mode from Vim. Even if our impl is different, it would be good to check with Vim if they want a similar feature and will use the same name. It's annoying for users if option names drift for no reason.

@justinmk actually I had made it such that it replaces the old behavior before, but my anxious mind thought, someone will tell me to make it optional so it will not break anything which i might be unaware of.  Also cause I had to change the tests, and it didn't feel right to make changes in test and thought someone will eventually point out this.
So I thought of making a new flag and creating it optional so both old tests and the tests I made for new behavior will pass. Also I have squashed all the old commits onto 1 commit cause it was pretty messy.
But I get what you are taking about I will make changes, so it directly uses the new behavior on `inline:word` instead of new flag `mergeblock`
Also with removal of mergeblocks flag, should I also remove it from options.lua and news.txt and make news.txt about change in default behaviour

I checked in Vim and in diff.c in Vim it appears the function `diff_refine_inline_char_highlight` which I took inspiration for `diff_refine_inline_word_highlight` function in my pr,  is entirely same with some minor formatting and is forked from vim onto the neovim, So I think this function can also be used in Vim

I've implemented something very similar to this in gitsigns which has had inline word diff for a while now. I found the gap threshold of 5 (instead of 2) to work the best so that may be a reason to have this configurable.

https://github.com/lewis6991/gitsigns.nvim/blob/main/lua%2Fgitsigns%2Fdiff_int.lua#L125-L146

With this added I'll be able to change gitsigns to use diffopts for this value which will be a plus.
@lewis6991 I am very grateful that you like this change that I made to the diffopt, and I would love to make this configurable!

@lewis6991 I have update the pr and now there is a `wordgap:` option which can be used to configure from 0(old behaviour) to 5 ### `set diffopt=internal,filler,inline:word,wordgap:0` ### `set diffopt=internal,filler,inline:word,wordgap:2` (default) ### `set diffopt=internal,filler,inline:word,wordgap:5` (max) I hope this is what you wanted to see! I will need to add tests for wordgap option later so making this pr drafted!
